is there any scenario in which UNICAST can be supported WITHOUT UNIQUE MAC AND IP ?? i think unicast traffic always requires unique L2 and L3 adresses. 

thats my humble opinion on the matter.

discussion.content: Layer 2 and 3 addresses have to be unique for VMs to establish proper TCP/IP communication.
The given answer is correct

choices.B: Each virtual machine requires a unique IP address but shares the MAC address with the physical server.
choices.D: Each virtual machine requires a unique MAC address but shares the IP address with the physical server.
choices.A: Virtual machines do not require a unique IP or unique MAC. They share the IP and MAC address of the physical server.
choices.C: Each virtual machine requires a unique IP and MAC addresses to be able to reach to other nodes.

questions.question_text: Which statement describes the IP and MAC allocation requirements for virtual machines on Type 1 hypervisors?

discussion.content:
Who the F chose B? Are you high?

Why would you want BPDUs sent on an access port?

Yes C is the answer, but you also have to remove bpduguard on the port and shut/no shut to bring it back up. so D is also an answer but only after you do C first.

Selected Answer: C
B is causing the issue. C is resolves it.
A link between two switches is FAR more likely to be a trunk than access. So C is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
The logging message indicates that a Bridge Protocol Data Unit (BPDU) was received on a non-trunk port, which suggests that the interface GigabitEthernet0/0 is not configured as a trunk port but is receiving 802.1Q tagged frames. To resolve this issue, you should configure the interface as a trunk port.
the output indicates that the G0/0 is not trunk! so it's C! the problem is B config
it must be defiantly a trunk port!

Two switches together... means you need trunk ports on both.. that resolves the issue, no if and or buts about it. any justifications for other answers means you need to go study more. This is fundamental.

Selected Answer: C
GigabitEthernet0/0

Selected Answer: C
c, it must be trunk to solve it
C'mon Admin...

It's obviously C.

The NON TRUNK G0/0 port on our switch is receving a TRUNK DOT1Q BPDU from the switch at the other end of the link. G0/0 on our switch is an Access port in VLAN 1. The port on the switch at the other end of the link is a trunk port. So the fix is to configure G0/0 on our switch as TRUNK.

Admins, please fix the answer.

this is a stupid question because it ask to fix problem but don't say how. I think the answer is correct because it dont talk of vlan.
If you need only one vlan the answer is correct.
B is the cause of the issue. C to resolve it

Selected Answer: B
The answer is 100% B here's why
On the Output Switch we received that error code, the Error code CLEARLY states that we received a NON_TRUNK and that we received a BPDU from an 802.1Q on our Trunk Interface g0/0 which means we are set to Trunk. 

You can't set to Trunk again because we are already set to trunk, if we switchport mode access the link will become operational.

Selected Answer: C
Port will be configured as trunk.

The interface will show a status of ‘BKN’ and a type of ‘P2p *TYPE_Inc’, you can also verify that with the command: show spanning-tree inconsistentports.

questions.question_text: By default, which virtual MAC address does HSRP group 12 use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The answer is B. Enable P2P Blocking.

Selected Answer: B
Definitively, B is the correct answer. P2P Blocking is the mechanism to block communications between host in the same SSID

It's B, but not "Enable". It should be "Disable" which allows P2P comms (graphic is correct) 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/7-5/configuration-guide/b_cg75/b_cg75_chapter_01001011.pdf

Choose one of the following options from the P2P Blocking drop-down list:

Disabled—Disables peer-to-peer blocking and bridges traffic locally within the controller whenever possible. This is the default value.

Note: Traffic is never bridged across VLANs in the controller.
Drop—Causes the controller to discard the packets.
Forward-UpStream—Causes the packets to be forwarded on the upstream VLAN. The device above the controller decides what action to take regarding the packets.
Cisco P2P blocking is there strange term for "Client Isolation" or "Guest network" private VLAN like functionality.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

AKA by every other vendor " Client Isolation" -_-

Selected Answer: B
P2P (Peer 2 Peer) Blocking

choices.C: They are placed into an inactive state.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Because VLAN 222 is an RSPAN VLAN, any access interfaces that are assigned to VLAN 222 will be placed into an inactive state. This means that they will not forward any traffic, except for traffic that is specifically destined for the switch.
C is correct

After the system is on, a SPAN or RSPAN destination session remains inactive until the destination port is operational. An RSPAN source session remains inactive until any of the source ports are operational or the RSPAN VLAN becomes active.

Selected Answer: C
